001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt;
002
003import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
004import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.MathTools;
005import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.BitConversion;
006
007import java.util.Random;
008
009/**
010 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the IPT color space.
011 * IPT has more perceptually-uniform handling of hue than some other color spaces, like YCwCm, and even
012 * though the version here gives up the complex exponential adjustments to various components that the original IPT
013 * paper used, it still is pretty good at preserving perceptual lightness. In most regards, this is a more
014 * thoroughly-constructed color space than YCwCm, but YCwCm may still be useful because of how it maps to aesthetic
015 * components of color. See {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} for docs on the I, P, and T channels.
016 */
017public class ColorTools {
018        /**
019         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, I (intensity or lightness), P
020         * (protan, a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish), T (tritan, a chromatic component ranging from
021         * bluish to yellowish), and A (alpha or opacity). Intensity should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for
022         * very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light colors (almost only white). Protan and tritan
023         * range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5. There's some aesthetic value in changing
024         * just one chroma value. When protan is high and tritan is low, the color is more purple/magenta, when both are low
025         * it is more bluish, when tritan is high and protan is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are high
026         * it tends to be orange. When protan and tritan are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha is the
027         * multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
028         * <br>
029         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
030         * intensity, protan, and tritan, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original I,
031         * P, and T values if the original values were in the range that {@link #intensity(float)}, {@link #protan(float)},
032         * and {@link #tritan(float)} return.
033         *
034         * @param intens     0f to 1f, intensity or I component of IPT, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
035         * @param protan     0f to 1f, protan or P component of IPT, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
036         * @param tritan     0f to 1f, tritan or T component of IPT, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
037         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
038         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
039         */
040        public static float ipt(float intens, float protan, float tritan, float alpha) {
041                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (tritan * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
042                                | ((int) (protan * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intens * 255) & 0xFF));
043        }
044
045        /**
046         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
047         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
048         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
049         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
050         */
051        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
052        {
053                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
054                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
055                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
056                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
057                final int r = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
058                final int g = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
059                final int b = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
060                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
061        }
062
063        /**
064         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
065         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
066         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
067         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
068         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
069         */
070        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
071        {
072                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
073                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
074                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
075                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
076                final int r = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
077                final int g = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
078                final int b = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
079                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
080        }
081
082        /**
083         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
084         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
085         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
086         */
087        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
088                final float r = (rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
089                final float g = (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
090                final float b = (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
091                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
092                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
093                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
094                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
095                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
096        }
097
098        /**
099         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
100         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
101         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
102         */
103        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
104                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
105                final float r = (abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
106                final float g = (abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
107                final float b = (abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
108
109                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
110                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
111                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
112                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
113                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
114        }
115
116        /**
117         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
118         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
119         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
120         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
121         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
122         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
123         */
124        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
125                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
126                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
127                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
128                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
129                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
130        }
131
132        /**
133         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
134         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
135         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
136         */
137        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
138        {
139                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
140                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
141                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
142                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
143                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
144        }
145
146        /**
147         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
148         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
149         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
150         */
151        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
152        {
153                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
154                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
155                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
156                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
157                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
158        }
159
160        /**
161         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
162         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
163         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
164         */
165        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
166        {
167                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
168                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
169                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
170                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
171                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
172        }
173
174        /**
175         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
176         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
177         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
178         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
179         */
180        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
181        {
182                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
183        }
184
185        /**
186         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
187         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
188         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
189         */
190        public static float red(final float encoded)
191        {
192                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
193                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
194                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
195                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
196                return Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
197        }
198
199        /**
200         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
201         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
202         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
203         */
204        public static float green(final float encoded)
205        {
206                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
207                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
208                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
209                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
210                return Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
211        }
212
213        /**
214         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
215         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
216         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
217         */
218        public static float blue(final float encoded)
219        {
220                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
221                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
222                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
223                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
224                return Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
225        }
226
227        /**
228         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
229         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
230         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
231         */
232        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
233        {
234                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
235        }
236
237        /**
238         * Gets a color as an IPT packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
239         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
240         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
241         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
242         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
243         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
244         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
245         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
246         *
247         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
248         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
249         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
250         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
251         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
252         */
253        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
254                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
255                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
256                } else {
257                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
258                }
259        }
260
261        /**
262         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
263         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
264         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
265         */
266        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
267                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
268                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
269                if(Math.abs(i - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
270                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
271                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
272                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
273                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
274                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
275                float x, y, w;
276                if(g < b) {
277                        x = b;
278                        y = g;
279                }
280                else {
281                        x = g;
282                        y = b;
283                }
284                if(r < x) {
285                        w = r;
286                }
287                else {
288                        w = x;
289                        x = r;
290                }
291                return x - Math.min(w, y);
292//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
293//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
294//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
295        }
296
297        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
298                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
299                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
300                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
301                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
302                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
303                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
304                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
305
306                float x, y, w;
307                if(g < b) {
308                        x = b;
309                        y = g;
310                }
311                else {
312                        x = g;
313                        y = b;
314                }
315                if(r < x) {
316                        w = r;
317                }
318                else {
319                        w = x;
320                        x = r;
321                }
322                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
323                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
324        }
325
326        /**
327         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
328         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
329         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
330         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
331         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
332         */
333        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
334                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
335                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
336                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
337                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
338                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
339                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
340                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
341                float x, y, z, w;
342                if(g < b) {
343                        x = b;
344                        y = g;
345                        z = -1f;
346                        w = 2f / 3f;
347                }
348                else {
349                        x = g;
350                        y = b;
351                        z = 0f;
352                        w = -1f / 3f;
353                }
354                if(r < x) {
355                        z = w;
356                        w = r;
357                }
358                else {
359                        w = x;
360                        x = r;
361                }
362                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
363                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
364        }
365
366        /**
367         * The "intensity" of the given packed float in IPT format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
368         * 1.0f . You can edit the intensity of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and
369         * {@link #darken(float, float)}.
370         *
371         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
372         * @return the intensity value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
373         */
374        public static float intensity(final float encoded)
375        {
376                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
377        }
378
379        /**
380         * The "protan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with tritan describes the
381         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If protan is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
382         * blue; if protan is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the protan of a color with
383         * {@link #protanUp(float, float)} and {@link #protanDown(float, float)}.
384         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
385         * @return the protan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
386         */
387        public static float protan(final float encoded)
388        {
389                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
390        }
391
392        /**
393         * The "tritan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with protan describes the
394         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If tritan is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
395         * blue or purple; if tritan is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
396         * the tritan of a color with {@link #tritanUp(float, float)} and {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}.
397         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
398         * @return the tritan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
399         */
400        public static float tritan(final float encoded)
401        {
402                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
403        }
404
405        /**
406         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
407         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not IPT! Takes
408         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
409         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
410         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
411         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
412         * <br>
413         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
414         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
415         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
416         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
417         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
418         *
419         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
420         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
421         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
422         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
423         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
424         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
425         */
426        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
427                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
428                final float i = Math.min(Math.max(light + (e & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
429                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
430                if (i <= 0.001f)
431                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
432                final float p = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
433                final float t = ((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
434                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
435                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
436                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
437                float x, y, z, w;
438                if(g < b) {
439                        x = b;
440                        y = g;
441                        z = -1f;
442                        w = 2f / 3f;
443                }
444                else {
445                        x = g;
446                        y = b;
447                        z = 0f;
448                        w = -1f / 3f;
449                }
450                if(r < x) {
451                        z = w;
452                        w = r;
453                }
454                else {
455                        w = x;
456                        x = r;
457                }
458                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
459                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
460                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
461                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
462                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
463        }
464
465        /**
466         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
467         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
468         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
469         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
470         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
471         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
472         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
473         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
474         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
475         */
476        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
477                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
478                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
479        }
480
481        /**
482         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
483         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
484         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
485         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
486         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
487         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
488         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
489         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
490         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
491         */
492        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
493                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
494                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
495        }
496
497        /**
498         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
499         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
500         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
501         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
502         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
503         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
504         * @see #protanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
505         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
506         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
507         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
508         */
509        public static float protanUp(final float start, final float change) {
510                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
511                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
512        }
513
514        /**
515         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
516         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
517         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
518         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
519         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
520         * intensity of start as-is.
521         * @see #protanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
522         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
523         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
524         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
525         */
526        public static float protanDown(final float start, final float change) {
527                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
528                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
529        }
530
531        /**
532         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
533         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
534         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
535         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
536         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
537         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and intensity of start as-is.
538         * @see #tritanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
539         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
540         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
541         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
542         */
543        public static float tritanUp(final float start, final float change) {
544                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
545                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
546        }
547
548        /**
549         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
550         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
551         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
552         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
553         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
554         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
555         * @see #tritanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
556         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
557         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
558         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
559         */
560        public static float tritanDown(final float start, final float change) {
561                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
562                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
563        }
564
565        /**
566         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
567         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
568         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
569         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
570         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
571         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
572         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
573         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
574         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
575         */
576        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
577                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
578                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
579        }
580
581        /**
582         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
583         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
584         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
585         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
586         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
587         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
588         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
589         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
590         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
591         */
592        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
593                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
594                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
595        }
596
597        /**
598         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
599         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
600         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes protan and tritan; it leaves intensity and alpha
601         * alone, unlike {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes intensity.
602         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
603         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
604         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
605         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
606         */
607        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
608                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
609                return ipt((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
610                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
611                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
612                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
613        }
614
615        /**
616         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
617         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
618         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only protan and tritan, but higher values for
619         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
620         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change intensity somewhat). If the color stays
621         * in-gamut, then intensity won't change; alpha never changes.
622         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
623         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
624         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
625         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
626         */
627        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
628                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
629                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
630                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
631                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
632                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
633        }
634
635        /**
636         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast with,
637         * gets a packed float IPT color with roughly inverted intnsity but the same chromatic channels and opacity (P and T
638         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
639         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
640         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
641         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the intensity unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
642         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
643         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
644         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
645         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
646         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
647         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
648         * @return a different IPT packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
649         */
650        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
651        {
652                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
653                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
654                                i = (bits & 0xff),
655                                p = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
656                                t = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
657                                ci = (contrastBits & 0xff),
658                                cp = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
659                                ct = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
660                if((p - cp) * (p - cp) + (t - ct) * (t - ct) >= 0x10000)
661                        return mainColor;
662                return ipt(ci < 128 ? i * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - i * (0.45f / 255f), p / 255f, t / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
663        }
664
665        /**
666         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast
667         * with, gets a packed float IPT color with I that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s I,
668         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
669         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
670         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
671         * <br>
672         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
673         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
674         * averages the original I of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
675         * @param mainColor a packed IPT float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
676         * @param contrastingColor a packed IPT float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the I of this
677         * @return a different packed IPT float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
678         */
679        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
680        {
681                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
682                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
683        }
684
685        /**
686         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's I and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
687         * with the original I. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
688         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
689         * @param mainColor a packed IPT float color
690         * @return a different packed IPT float color, with its I channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
691         */
692        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
693                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
694                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
695        }
696
697        /**
698         * Makes the additive IPT color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
699         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
700         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
701         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
702         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
703         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
704         * @return an IPT float color between gray and {@code color}
705         */
706        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
707                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
708                                is = 0x80, ps = 0x80, ts = 0x80, as = 0xFE,
709                                ie = (e & 0xFF), pe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, te = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
710                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (is + fraction * (ie - is)) & 0xFF)
711                                | (((int) (ps + fraction * (pe - ps)) & 0xFF) << 8)
712                                | (((int) (ts + fraction * (te - ts)) & 0xFF) << 16)
713                                | (((int) (as + fraction * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
714        }
715
716        /**
717         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
718         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
719         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
720         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
721         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the I, P, and T of the
722         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
723         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers P and T extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while I goes from 0 to 1,
724         * but only internally for measuring distance).
725         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
726         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
727         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
728         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
729         */
730        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
731                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
732                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
733                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
734                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
735                final float limit = variance * variance;
736                float dist, x, y, z;
737                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
738                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
739                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
740                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
741                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
742                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
743                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += i, y = (p + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (t + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
744                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
745                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
746                }
747                return color;
748        }
749
750        /**
751         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as IPT, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
752         * @param packed a packed float color as IPT
753         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
754         */
755        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
756        {
757                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
758                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
759                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
760                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
761                final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t;
762                if(r < -0.006f || r > 1.003f) return false;
763                final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t;
764                if(g < -0.006f || g > 1.003f)
765                        return false;
766                final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t;
767                return (b >= -0.006f && b <= 1.003f);
768        }
769        /**
770         * Returns true if the given IPT values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
771         * @param i intensity channel, as a float from 0 to 1
772         * @param p protan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
773         * @param t tritan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
774         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
775         */
776        public static boolean inGamut(float i, float p, float t)
777        {
778                p = (p - 0.5f) * 2f;
779                t = (t - 0.5f) * 2f;
780                final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t;
781                if(r < -0.006f || r > 1.003f) return false;
782                final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t;
783                if(g < -0.006f || g > 1.003f)
784                        return false;
785                final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t;
786                return (b >= -0.006f && b <= 1.003f);
787        }
788
789        /**
790         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
791         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
792         * @param packed a packed float color in IPT format; often this color is not in-gamut
793         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
794         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
795         */
796        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
797                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
798                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
799                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
800                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
801                float i2 = i, p2 = p, t2 = t;
802                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
803                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
804                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
805                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
806                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
807                                break;
808                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
809                        i2 = MathTools.lerp(0.5f, i, progress);
810                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
811                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
812                }
813                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
814        }
815
816        /**
817         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
818         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
819         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
820         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
821         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
822         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
823         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
824         */
825        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t) {
826                return limitToGamut(i, p, t, 1f);
827        }
828        /**
829         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
830         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
831         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
832         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
833         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
834         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
835         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
836         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
837         */
838        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t, float a) {
839                float i2 = i = Math.min(Math.max(i, 0f), 1f);
840                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max((p - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
841                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max((t - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
842                a = Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f);
843                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
844                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
845                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
846                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
847                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
848                                break;
849                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
850                        i2 = MathTools.lerp(0.5f, i, progress);
851                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
852                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
853                }
854                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, a);
855        }
856
857        /**
858         * Converts from a packed float in HSI format to a packed float in IPT format.
859         * @param packed a packed float in HSI format
860         * @return a packed float in IPT format
861         */
862        public static float fromHSI(float packed){
863                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
864                final float h = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
865                final float s = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
866                final float i = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
867                final float y = MathTools.cos_(h) * s, z = MathTools.sin_(h) * s;
868                final float crMid = 0.3481738f * y + 0.104959644f * z;
869                final float crScale = (i - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(crMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16420607f / -crMid;
870                final float mgMid = 0.122068435f * y + -0.070396f * z;
871                final float mgScale = (i + 0.5f - (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mgMid) >>> 31)) * -0.16136102f / -mgMid;
872                final float ybMid = 0.020876605f * y + -0.26078433f * z;
873                final float ybScale = (i - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(ybMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16155326f / -ybMid;
874                final float scale = Math.max(crScale, Math.max(mgScale, ybScale));
875                final float d = 4f * s * scale / (MathTools.sin(3.14159f * i) + 0.000001f);
876
877                final float p = y * d;
878                final float t = z * d;
879                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (t * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
880                                | ((int) (p * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF));
881        }
882
883        /**
884         * Converts from hue, saturation, intensity, and alpha components (each ranging from 0 to 1 inclusive) to a packed
885         * float color in IPT format.
886         * @param hue hue, from 0 to 1 inclusive; 0 is red, 0.25 is yellow, 0.75 is blue
887         * @param saturation saturation from 0 (grayscale) to a limit between 0 and 1 depending on intensity (it can be 1 only when intensity is 0.5)
888         * @param intensity intensity, or lightness, from 0 (black) to 1 (white)
889         * @param alpha alpha transparency/opacity, from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque)
890         * @return a packed float in IPT format
891         */
892        public static float fromHSI(float hue, float saturation, float intensity, float alpha){
893                final float y = MathTools.cos_(hue) * saturation, z = MathTools.sin_(hue) * saturation;
894                final float crMid = 0.3481738f * y + 0.104959644f * z;
895                final float crScale = (intensity - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(crMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16420607f / -crMid;
896                final float mgMid = 0.122068435f * y + -0.070396f * z;
897                final float mgScale = (intensity + 0.5f - (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mgMid) >>> 31)) * -0.16136102f / -mgMid;
898                final float ybMid = 0.020876605f * y + -0.26078433f * z;
899                final float ybScale = (intensity - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(ybMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16155326f / -ybMid;
900                final float scale = Math.max(crScale, Math.max(mgScale, ybScale));
901                final float d = 4f * saturation * scale / (MathTools.sin(3.14159f * intensity) + 0.000001f);
902
903                final float p = y * d;
904                final float t = z * d;
905                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int)(alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (t * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
906                                | ((int) (p * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intensity * 255) & 0xFF));
907        }
908
909        /**
910         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
911         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.LaserRandom})
912         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
913         */
914        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
915                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
916                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
917                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
918                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
919                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
920                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
921                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
922                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
923        }
924        /**
925         * Limited-use; like {@link #randomColor(Random)} but for cases where you already have three floats (r, g, and b)
926         * distributed how you want. This can be somewhat useful if you are using a "subrandom" or "quasi-random" sequence,
927         * like the Halton, Sobol, or R3 sequences, to get 3D points and map them to colors. It can also be useful if you
928         * want to randomly generate the RGB channels yourself and track the values produced, as you would if you wanted to
929         * avoid generating too many colors with high blue, for instance. This approximately maps the r, g, and b parameters
930         * to distances on the RGB axes of a rectangular prism, which is stretched and rotated to form the IPT gamut.
931         * @param r red value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
932         * @param g green value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
933         * @param b blue value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
934         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
935         */
936        public static float subrandomColor(float r, float g, float b) {
937                r = Math.min(Math.max(r, 0f), 0.999f);
938                g = Math.min(Math.max(g, 0f), 0.999f);
939                b = Math.min(Math.max(b, 0f), 0.999f);
940                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
941                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
942                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
943                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
944                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
945                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
946                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 255f) & 0xFF));
947        }
948}
